rsbNotes.title: Acts 12:3
rsbNotes.text:
12:3 it pleased the Jews . . . arrest Peter also. God’s sovereign purpose was carried out in the lives of His equally dedicated servants: at this time James died by the sword, while Peter was delivered from prison.

during the days of Unleavened Bread. With so many zealous Jews visiting the city at the feast, it was an opportune time to make the arrest.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 12:7
rsbNotes.text: 12:7 an angel of the Lord . . . a light shone. An angel was an assurance of God’s presence, and the light would probably remind Peter of the Old Testament glory of the Lord (9:3; Ex. 3:2; 13:22; 40:34).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 12:10
rsbNotes.text: 12:10 iron gate leading into the city. The Antonian Fortress had an entrance into the temple courts on the south as well as other entrances to the city.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 12:15–16
rsbNotes.text: 12:15, 16 The disciples prayed fervently to God (cf. 4:23, 24) to protect and deliver Peter, but then failed to believe that the Lord had done what they requested.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 12:15
rsbNotes.text: 12:15 his angel. They thought it was his personal angelic guardian (Matt. 18:10; Heb. 1:14). The popular conception was that such a guardian could assume the appearance of the human person protected.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 12:19
rsbNotes.text: 12:19 put to death. According to Roman law, if a prisoner escaped, the guard was liable to be punished as the prisoner would have been (cf. 16:27, 28).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 12:23
rsbNotes.text:
12:23 did not give God the glory. In his pride, he accepted for himself the praise that belongs to God.

eaten by worms. The Jewish historian Josephus (Antiquities 19.346–350) records that Herod Agrippa I experienced heart pains together with pain in his abdomen and died after five days. Herod died in a.d. 44, the fourth year of Claudius Caesar.
